content: Provide a comprehensive list of at least ten distinct celestial objects, both natural and artificial, located within the vast expanse of the Milky Way Galaxy. Please include a detailed description of each object, including its physical characteristics, location within the galaxy, and any relevant historical or scientific significance. Furthermore, please categorize each object based on its respective celestial classification (e.g., star, planet, black hole, supernova remnant) and provide a brief explanation of why it belongs to that category. Your answer should be well-organized and formatted as a table, with each object corresponding to a separate row and its corresponding attributes listed in columns.

Here's a comprehensive table of ten distinct celestial objects within the Milky Way Galaxy, both natural and artificial, along with their descriptions, classifications, and other relevant information:

| Name                     | Classification       | Description                                                                                                                                           | Location within Galaxy     | Significance                                                                                              |
|--------------------------|----------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|----------------------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Sun                      | Star (G-type main-sequence) | The Sun is the closest star to Earth and the center of our solar system, providing light and heat necessary for life.                                 | Orion Arm                  | Essential for life on Earth; enables study of stellar processes.                                          |
| Sagittarius A*           | Black Hole           | A supermassive black hole located at the center of the Milky Way, with a mass about 4 million times that of the Sun.                                  | Galactic Center            | Key to understanding the dynamics of our galaxy and the role of black holes in galaxy formation.          |
| Alpha Centauri           | Star System          | The closest star system to the Solar System, consisting of three stars: Alpha Centauri A, B, and Proxima Centauri, the latter being the closest star. | Near Solar System          | Important for studies of potentially habitable exoplanets like Proxima b.                                 |
| Betelgeuse               | Red Supergiant Star  | A large, aging star nearing the end of its life cycle, known for its distinctive red color and brightness.                                            | Orion Constellation        | A future supernova candidate, providing insight into stellar evolution and death.                         |
| Andromeda Galaxy         | Galaxy               | Though technically not within the Milky Way, it is the nearest spiral galaxy and on a collision course with the Milky Way.                            | Neighboring Galaxy         | Offers insight into galaxy formation and potential future of the Milky Way.                               |
| Voyager 1                | Space Probe          | An artificial object launched by NASA in 1977, now in interstellar space, carrying a golden record of Earth sounds and images.                        | Heliosphere's outer edge   | Provides valuable data on the outer solar system and interstellar space.                                  |
| Crab Nebula              | Supernova Remnant    | The remnant of a supernova explosion observed in 1054 AD, composed of a pulsar and expanding gas cloud.                                               | Taurus Constellation       | Helps in the study of supernovae and neutron stars.                                                       |
| Kepler-186f              | Exoplanet            | An Earth-sized exoplanet located in the habitable zone of its star, potentially capable of supporting liquid water.                                   | Cygnus Constellation       | Important for the study of potentially habitable worlds beyond our solar system.                          |
| Messier 13 (Hercules Cluster) | Globular Cluster     | A dense collection of hundreds of thousands of stars, one of the brightest and best-known globular clusters.                                          | Hercules Constellation     | Offers insights into the early formation of the Milky Way and the evolution of stars.                     |
| International Space Station (ISS) | Space Station        | A habitable artificial satellite in low Earth orbit, serving as a microgravity research laboratory.                                                    | Low Earth Orbit            | Supports international collaboration in space research and development of human spaceflight capabilities. |

Each of these objects belongs to its respective celestial classification based on its inherent characteristics and phenomena. For example, stars like the Sun and Betelgeuse are categorized by their nuclear fusion processes and lifecycle stages, while black holes like Sagittarius A* are defined by their intense gravitational fields and singularities. Artificial objects like the Voyager 1 and ISS represent human endeavours in space exploration and habitation.
